children.name: an idea or set of ideas that explains sth
idea
children.definition: a way of explaining something about life, society, etc: tư tưởng
examples: Ideas and customs used to be passed on intact down the generations.
Do you agree generally with Marx’s ideas?
idea about
She had some rather unusual ideas about raising children.
medieval ideas about the origins of the universe
idea that
How old is the idea that there is life after death?
idea of
Ideas of how society should function have changed dramatically in the last 200 years.
where did you get that idea?(= used to say that what someone thinks is completely wrong )
No, I’m not seeing Jane. Where did you get that idea?

children.name: theory
children.definition: 1 an idea or set of ideas that is intended to explain something about life or the world, especially an idea that has not yet been proved to be true →theoretical: thuyết học, thuyết
examples: theory about/on
different theories about how the brain works
theory of
Darwin’s theory of evolution
sb’s theory of sth
Darwin’s Theory of Evolution
Einstein’s theory of relativity
theory that
the theory that light is made up of waves
2[U] general principles and ideas about a subject : thuyết, lý thuyết
Freudian theory has had a great influence on psychology.
political/economic/literary etc theory
I’m taking a course on political theory.

children.name: come up with/develop a theory
examples: These birds helped Darwin develop his theory of natural selection.

children.name: test a theory
examples: Researchers gave workers a questionnaire to test that theory.

children.name: prove a theory
examples: No evidence emerged to prove either theory.

children.name: support a theory
examples: Modern research strongly supports this theory.

children.name: disprove a theory
children.definition: alsorefute a theoryformal
examples: (= show that it is wrong )Later experiments seemed to disprove the theory.

children.name: discredit a theory
children.definition: make people stop believing in it
examples: These latest findings discredit his entire theory.

children.name: a scientific theory
examples: Scientific theories can be tested experimentally.

children.name: an economic theory
examples: His economic theory assumes that both labour and capital are perfectly mobile.

children.name: a conspiracy theory
children.definition: a theory that an event was the result of secret plan made by two or more people
examples: A variety of conspiracy theories question the official account of President Kennedy’s assassination.

children.name: a pet theory
children.definition: a personal theory that you strongly believe
examples: Each of them had his pet theory on what had caused the uprising.

children.name: the theory of evolution/relativity etc
examples: According to the theory of relativity, nothing can travel faster than light.

children.name: hypothesis
children.definition: an idea that is based on very few facts and that you cannot be sure is right: giả thuyết
examples: Various hypotheses are possible regarding the nature and structure of the world.
The results of our experiment confirmed this hypothesis.
One hypothesis is that the victim fell asleep while driving.

children.name: prove/test/support etc a hypothesis
examples: We hope that further research will confirm our hypothesis.

children.name: hypothesis about
examples: The authors reject the hypothesis about unemployment contributing to crime.

children.name: premise
children.definition: a statement or idea that you accept as being true and use as a base for developing other ideas: tiên đề, giả định
examples: American justice works on the premise that an accused person is innocent until they are proved guilty.
I believe his whole argument is based on a false premise.
The idea that there is life on other planets is the central premise of the novel.
premise that
the premise that an accused person is innocent until they are proved guilty

children.name: notion
children.definition: a way of explaining something about life, society, etc, that people often think is a littlestupidorold-fashioned: khái niệm, ý niệm (ngu ngốc , lỗi thời )
examples: notion of
misguided notions of male superiority
The traditional notion of marriage goes back thousands of years.
notion that
the notion that human beings are basically good

children.name: have a notion
examples: He didn’t have a clear notion of what he had to do.

children.name: accept a notion
examples: Probably 95% of scientists now accept the notion that human activity is causing climate change.

children.name: support a notion
examples: There is no evidence to support the notion that girls are treated better than boys in school.

children.name: reinforce a notion
children.definition: make an idea stronger or easier to believe
examples: The research reinforces the notion that fathers have an important role in their children’s lives.

children.name: challenge/dispute a notion
examples: Copernicus challenged the notion that the sun goes around the earth.

children.name: reject/dismiss a notion
examples: Aristotle rejected the notion that the body and the soul are separate.

children.name: a vague notion
children.definition: an unclear idea
examples: He had only a vague notion of what might happen next.

children.name: an absurd/ridiculous notion
examples: They had the ridiculous notion that they could make a living from singing.

children.name: a simple notion
examples: You cannot rate the project according to a simple notion of ‘value for money’: there are too many factors involved.

children.name: an abstract notion
examples: In art, how can you represent abstract notions such as peace or justice?

children.name: a romantic notion
children.definition: one that is based on how you want something to be, not how it is in real life
examples: He rejected the romantic notion of rugby as a game for gentlemen.

children.name: a preconceived notion
children.definition: an idea that you have before you have enough knowledge or experience
examples: The police were accused of twisting the evidence to meet their preconceived notion of his guilt.

children.name: an accepted/received notion
children.definition: an idea that most people believe
examples: These women challenged accepted notions of female roles in society.

children.name: the whole notion of something
children.definition: used to emphasize that you are talking about a lot of related ideas, not just one specific idea
examples: The movie makes us question the whole notion of what makes a hero.

children.name: not have the faintest/foggiest notion
children.definition: not know or understand something at all
examples: He had not the foggiest notion how far he might have to walk.

children.name: concept
children.definition: an idea of how something is, or how something should be done: khái niệm
examples: concept of
the concept of total patient care
the concept of infinite space
concept that
the concept that we are citizens of one world

children.name: a new concept
examples: Part of a teacher’s job is to introduce new concepts to students.

children.name: a basic/fundamental concept
examples: The children are taught the basic concepts of mathematics.

children.name: a key/central/important concept
examples: The title tells you something about the central concept of the poem.

children.name: a difficult concept
examples: Difficult concepts can sometimes be explained by diagrams or graphs.

children.name: a simple concept
examples: Cause and effect is a fairly simple concept.

children.name: the whole concept of something
examples: Some people reject the whole concept of evolution.

children.name: a general/broad concept
examples: The book begins with some general historical concepts.

children.name: an abstract concept
children.definition: based on general ideas rather than on something that exists
examples: He finds it hard to grasp abstract concepts.

children.name: a theoretical concept
children.definition: that exists only as a theory
examples: The theoretical concepts of psychology, for example Freud’s ideas, are also useful in the study of literature.

children.name: a legal/mathematical/marketing etc concept
examples: Democracy is a very important political concept.

children.name: an alien concept
children.definition: an idea that is very strange or that does not exist
examples: In many countries, queuing for a bus is an alien concept.

children.name: an ambiguous/vague concept
children.definition: one that is not clear or is hard to define
examples: Creativity is an ambiguous concept.

children.name: have a concept of something
examples: Animals have no concept of their own mortality.

children.name: understand a concept
examples: The class will help you understand the basic concepts of physics.

children.name: grasp a concept
children.definition: understand it
examples: Children often grasp new concepts more quickly than adults.

children.name: introduce a concept
examples: The first year of the course introduces the basic concepts of management.

children.name: develop a concept
examples: The Greeks developed the concept of a scientific theory.

children.name: gist
children.definition: the main idea and meaning of sth such as an article or a speech: thực chất, ý chính

children.name: the gist of sth
examples: ▪ I don’t know the whole story but this is the gist of it.

children.name: get the gist (of sth)understand the gist of something
examples: ▪ Read the article once through to get the gist of it.
▪ Students are encouraged to read the text, getting the gist, then go deeper into the meaning.

children.name: point
children.definition: the main idea of an argument, discussion, statement etc that shows its general or most important meaning:
examples: The point is, at least we’re all safely back home.
Nobody knows exactly how it works. That’sthe whole point.
He may not have stolen the money himself, butthat’s not the point.
I need to find out who killed Alf, andmore to the point(= what is more important )I need to do it before anyone else gets killed.
We all like him, but that’sbeside the point(= not the most important thing ).

children.name: the point is
children.definition: that
examples: ...The point is that going by bus would be a lot cheaper.

children.name: that’s the
children.definition: whole
examples: pointThat’s the point. She didn’t tell us what was going on.

children.name: that's not the point
examples: We'd earn a lot of money, but that's not the point.

children.name: be beside the point
children.definition: be not the most important thing to consider
examples: He's the best person for the job so his age is beside the point.

children.name: more to the point
children.definition: what is more important
examples: When did she leave, and, more to the point, why?

children.name: get/come
children.definition: straight
examples: to the point(= talk about the most important thing immediately )I haven't got much time so let's get straight to the point.

children.name: get the point
children.definition: understand it
examples: He didn’t get the point at first.

children.name: miss the point
children.definition: not understand it
examples: I don't know why but Mel always seems to miss the point.

children.name: sb’s point
examples: What’s your point? Do you think I’m not good enough for your daughter?

children.name: the point of sth
examples: The point of the story did not emerge until the end of the film.

children.name: essence
children.definition: the most important meaning of sth such as an argument or piece of writing: cốt lõi, thực chất

children.name: the essence of sth
examples: The essence of Arsenal’s style of football was speed.
She seemsthe very essence ofkindness(= she seems very kind ).
in essenceused when talking about the most basic and important part of something, especially an idea, belief, or argument :
In essence his message was very simple.
The essence of his argument is that human character is formed by society.

children.name: drift
children.definition: the main set of ideas involved in sth such as an explanation, argument, or account of sth: ý định, chủ ý

children.name: the drift of sth
examples: The drift of his letter is that he wants to come back.

children.name: catch/get/follow sb’s driftunderstand the basic idea of what someone is saying
examples: It was a complicated argument but I think I caught his drift.
I follow your drift, but I just don’t believe it.

children.name: thrust
children.definition: the most important message of an argument, explanation etc, especially when it consists of a set of connected ideas leading to a final answer or idea:
examples: the thrust of sth
It is difficult to argue with the thrust of Davidson’s analysis of the situation.
The overall thrust of her argument was that women are still oppressed in all areas of life.
the main thrust
the main idea, subject, or opinion that is discussed or written about

children.name: substance
children.definition: the most important ideas contained in an argument or piece of writing: thực chất, cốt lõi, căn bản

children.name: the substance of sth
examples: The substance of Marx’s views is the same in both of these books.
The substance of his argumentwas that people on welfare should work.

children.name: in substance
examples: What she said, in substance, was that the mayor should resign.

children.name: thought
children.definition: an idea - use this especially when youhave not yet consideredit carefully: ý nghĩ , ý tưởng
examples: That’s an interesting thought. Let’s discuss it at the meeting.
What are your thoughts, Michael?
thoughts on
Any thoughts on how we should spend the money?
If you have any thoughts on the matter, let me know.
sb’s thoughts about sth
I’d like you to begin by writing down your thoughts about the play.
it was (just/only) a thoughtspoken say this when someone seems to disagree with your idea
‘That’s not a very good time of year to travel.’ ‘Perhaps not. It was just a thought.’
a comforting thought‘People might not have noticed we’re late.’ ‘That’s a comforting thought.’

children.name: have a thought
examples: I just had a funny thought.

children.name: express your thoughts
children.definition: say what they are or tell other people about them
examples: He was finding it difficult to express his thoughts.

children.name: a thought occurs to/comes to/strikes somebody
children.definition: someone suddenly has a thought
examples: The thought occurred to him that she might be lying.

children.name: a thought crosses sb’s mind
children.definition: someone has a thought
examples: The thought never crossed my mind that I could be wrong.

children.name: can’t bear the thought of something
examples: I can’t bear the thought of you being hurt.

children.name: sb’s thoughts turn to something
children.definition: they start thinking about something
examples: As summer approaches, people’s thoughts turn to holidays.

children.name: sb’s first thought
examples: My first thought was that a bomb had gone off.

children.name: a passing thought
children.definition: a quick, not very serious thought
examples: He never gives his appearance more than a passing thought.

children.name: a sobering thought
children.definition: one that makes you feel serious
examples: We have the power to destroy the world, which is a sobering thought.

children.name: horrible/disturbing
examples: A horrible thought struck her: could he be having an affair?

children.name: a sudden thought
examples: A sudden thought struck her and she began to laugh.

children.name: the very thought
children.definition: even the idea of doing something
examples: The very thought of going on stage made her feel ill.

children.name: idea
children.definition: a plan or suggestion for a possible course of action, especially one that you think of suddenly: ý tưởng
examples: You should talk to Ken - he's always full of good ideas.
I knew it was a bad idea to leave him on his own.
It was my wife’s idea to move house.

children.name: have an idea
examples: I’ve had an idea. Why don’t we walk into town?

children.name: get an idea
examples: She got the idea from an article in a magazine.

children.name: give somebody an idea
examples: What gave you the idea for the book?

children.name: come up with an idea
children.definition: think of an idea
examples: He’s always coming up with interesting ideas.

children.name: hit on an ideainformal
children.definition: suddenly think of an idea
examples: Then we hit on the idea of renting a cottage.

children.name: toy with an ideainformal
children.definition: think about using an idea, but not very seriously
examples: I’m toying with the idea of going back to college.

children.name: brainstorm ideas
children.definition: get a group of people to all try and think of ideas
examples: We had a meeting to brainstorm ideas for the new advertising campaign.

children.name: share/exchange ideas
children.definition: tell someone else your ideas, and learn their ideas
examples: an opportunity for local business people to share ideas

children.name: an idea comes to somebody
children.definition: someone suddenly thinks of an idea
examples: The idea came to me while I was having a bath.

children.name: a good/bad idea
examples: Keeping the drinks cold in the bath was a good idea.|Knocking down this wall was a really bad idea.

children.name: a great/brilliant/excellent idea
examples: What a great idea!

children.name: a bright idea
children.definition: a very good idea - often used ironically
examples: Whose bright idea was it to leave the washing out in the rain?

children.name: a clever idea
examples: It seemed like a clever idea at the time.

children.name: interesting
examples: The idea sounded interesting , but I didn’t think it would work.

children.name: stupid/ridiculous/crazy
examples: The idea sounded crazy to me.|Camping in the middle of winter was a ridiculous idea!|He had the crazy idea of hitchhiking around South America.

children.name: original/innovative
children.definition: no one has thought of it before
examples: The company is looking for people who can come up with original ideas.

children.name: a half-baked idea
children.definition: an idea that has not been carefully thought out
examples: It’s yet another of the government’s half-baked ideas.

children.name: be full of ideas
children.definition: alsobe bursting with ideas
examples: (= have a lot of ideas )The children were enthusiastic and full of ideas.

children.name: fire/bounce ideas off one another
children.definition: discuss each other’s ideas and think of good new ones
examples: Our regular meetings are opportunities to fire ideas off each other.

children.name: idea for
examples: The idea for the book came from an old war movie.

children.name: the idea of (doing) sth
examples: The idea of an underground garage in the park has provoked a lot of anger.
I had the idea of asking Katie for help.

children.name: idea to do sth
examples: Who’s idea was it to ask him to the party?

children.name: idea that
examples: Nobody seemed very keen on the idea that we should all dress up for the party.

children.name: it was sb’s ideathey thought of it đó là ý của ai đó
examples: I never wanted to go to Spain. It was Sue’s idea.
►Do not say ‘the idea to do something’. Saythe idea of doing something.However, you can sayit is a good idea to do somethingandit was someone’s idea to do something.

children.name: good/great/fantastic etc idea
children.definition: especially spoken: ý tưởng hay, tốt, tuyệt vời

children.name: ‘We could go and see a movie.’ ‘Good idea!’
examples: I think a skiing holiday is a brilliant idea.
That’s a great idea! Let’s call Madge and see if she can come too.

children.name: bright idea
children.definition: a very good idea that you think of suddenly. This is sometimes also used when you think that sb’s idea is not good: ý tưởng sáng suốt
examples: Why not ask Sylvia? She’s always full of bright ideas.
whose bright idea was it...used when you think sth is a bad idea ai đã nghĩ ra cái ý sáng suốt là...
Whose bright idea was it to start major road repairs right at the start of the holiday season?

children.name: brainwave
children.definition: UK/brainstormUS  informal a sudden, very good idea: ý tưởng hay, sáng kiến, "sóng não"
examples: Unless sb comes up with a brainwave soon, I can’t see how we can possibly get out of this mess.

children.name: have a brainwave
examples: Then Mo had a brainstorm. She would start her own coffee bar for teenagers.

children.name: stroke of genius
children.definition: a very good and original idea about what to do or how to deal with a problem: sáng kiến thiên tài
examples: They named the new car ‘Thunderbird.’ It was a stroke of genius.
At first, the manager’s appointment of talented but inexperienced players seemed like a stroke of genius.

children.name: have an idea
children.definition: có một ý tưởng, nghĩ ra 1 ý tưởng
examples: ▪ I’ve had an idea. What do you think about going to Greece this summer?
▪ That’s the best idea you’ve had all day.

children.name: have an idea for
examples: ▪ Do you have any ideas for a birthday present for Mum?

children.name: have the idea of doing sth
examples: ▪ He had the idea of hiding Ali’s shoes.

children.name: get an idea
children.definition: to think of an idea - use this especially to say what made you think of it or to ask sb what made them think of it: có được ý tưởng
examples: ▪ Where on earth did you get that idea?

children.name: get the idea for sth
examples: ▪ Mark got the idea for the novel when he was in Boston in 1969.

children.name: get an idea from
examples: ▪ It wasn’t my own idea. I got it from a TV movie.

children.name: get the idea of doing sth
examples: ▪ She first got the idea of working with elderly people after the death of her mother.

children.name: get an idea that
examples: ▪ I don’t know how she got the idea that she was too fat.

children.name: think of
children.definition: sth to have an idea about what to do, how to do sth etc: nghĩ ra
examples: At first, we couldn’t think of a name for the band.
Seth decided to go home. He couldn’t think of anything else to do.
Ask Dad. He might be able to think of a solution.
We'll have to think of a pretty good excuse for being late.

children.name: come to
children.definition: sb if an idea comes to sb, they have the ideasuddenlyand without trying hard to think of it: đến với ai
examples: ▪ The idea for the new advertising campaign came to me while I was visiting Thailand.

children.name: it came to sb that
examples: ▪ It suddenly came to me that I’d seen her somewhere before.

children.name: come to sb in a flashvery suddenly
examples: ▪ It came to Blake in a flash that the man was really a detective.

children.name: hit on
children.definition: /upon sth informal to have a good idea after thinking about or working on a problem for a long time: bật lên ý tưởng
examples: At last we hit on a way of getting Tom and Marcia to meet.
The architects finally hit upon a design that seemed to please everyone.

children.name: be inspired by
children.definition: if sb’s plan, work of art, action etc is inspired by sth, that is what gave them the idea to do it: được truyền cảm hứng bởi
examples: The novel was inspired by her own experiences in India.
Some of Picasso’s work was inspired by African art.
The 1911 strike was inspired by the revolutionary ideas flooding out of Europe at that time.

children.name: imaginative
children.definition: / inventive approving containing new ideas that are used in interesting and original ways: giàu tưởng tượng
examples: ▪ The film uses computer graphics in an unusual and highly imaginative way.

children.name: ▪ an imaginative solution to the city’s crime problem
examples: ▪ These figures are some of the most inventive of all African tribal sculptures.
▪ Inside the magazine you will find plenty of inventive ideas for redecorating your home.

children.name: an imaginative new approach/policy
examples: The architects have made imaginative use of glass and transparent plastic.

children.name: abstract
children.definition: adjectiveGENERALtrừu tượng

children.name: existing as an idea, feeling or quality, not as a material object
examples: _Truth and beauty are abstract concepts.

children.name: content
children.definition: the ideas, facts, or opinions that are contained in a speech or piece of writing:
examples: ▪ Many of the essays are political in content.
▪ The software, designed for children, has good graphics and animation that doesn’t overwhelm the content.
content of
▪ People pay as much attention to your voice as to the content of your speech.
contentnounSUBJECTnội dung
[ S or U ] the ideas that are contained in a piece of writing, a speech or a film
_It's a very stylish and beautiful film, but it lacks content.
_We've discussed the unusual form of the book - now, what about the content?

children.name: idea
children.definition: nounKNOWLEDGEý nghĩ

children.name: the/sb's point
children.definition: the meaning or most important part of what someone says or writes
examples: _The point is, if you don't claim the money now you might never get it.
_I think youmissed(= did not understand) the point of what she was saying.
_Itakeyour point/Pointtaken(= I understand that what you are saying is important) .
_Pleaseget tothe point (= say the thing that is most important to you) .
_He hasn't got much money, but that's not the point (= that is not the important thing) .

children.name: conception
children.definition: nounIDEA quan niệm

children.name: principle
children.definition: nounBASIC IDEAnguyên lý, nguyên tắc
examples: [ C ] a basic idea or rule that explains or controls how something happens or works
_the principles of the criminal justice system
_The country is runonsocialist principles.
_The machine works according to the principleofelectromagnetic conduction.
_The organization workson theprinciplethatall members have the same rights.
